===Police brutality===
===Police brutality===
  +
{{main|Law enforcement in Egypt}}
  +   +
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarak's ruling party, ''Baltageya''<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash"/> ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author= Kirkpatrick, David; Fahim, Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>

{{main|Law enforcement in Egypt}}
  â   â
The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarak's ruling party, ''Baltageya''<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash"/> ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.<ref name="Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author= Kirkpatrick, David; Fahim, Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> Activists rallying around a Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" succeeded in bringing nationwide attention to the case.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=Wall Street Journal |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>

Line 56: Line 56:
===Economic climate===
===Economic climate===
{{Main|Economy of Egypt}}
{{Main|Economy of Egypt}}
â
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cairo neighborhood.jpg|thumb|A neighborhood in Cairo]]
 
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and current President Hosni Mubarak. Cairo from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Egypt's economy was highly centralized during the rule of former President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under former President Anwar Sadat and current President Hosni Mubarak. Cairo from 2004 to 2008 aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5 percent in 2009. In 2010, analysts assessed the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions for the broader population. Despite high levels of economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2010|source=[[CIA World Factbook]]|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
In late 2010 around 40 percent of Egypt's population of just under 80 million lived on the fiscal income equivalent of roughly US$2 per day and a large part of the population relied on subsidised goods.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], the basic problem Egypt has is unemployment driven by a demographic bulge: with the number of new people entering the job force at about 4 percent a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for college graduates as it is for people who have gone through elementary school, particularly educated urban youth, who are precisely the people currently seen out in the streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/|title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome|work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
In late 2010 around 40 percent of Egypt's population of just under 80 million lived on the fiscal income equivalent of roughly US$2 per day and a large part of the population relied on subsidised goods.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/> According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], the basic problem Egypt has is unemployment driven by a demographic bulge: with the number of new people entering the job force at about 4 percent a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for college graduates as it is for people who have gone through elementary school, particularly educated urban youth, who are precisely the people currently seen out in the streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/|title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome|work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
